facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 251 of 1958 appealed from Mysore High Court judgment dated February 26, 1958 in Misc. Appeal No. 142 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 251 of 1958. Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 26, 1958, of the Mysore High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 142 of 1957.

facts.text: Election held on March 8, 1957 for Mysore State Legislative Assembly, Harihar constituency

anchor.surface_text: The election with which the case is companycerned, was held on March 8, 1957, for choosing members for the Mysore State Legislative Assembly. One of the companystituencies for the pu

facts.text: Nomination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao rejected by Returning Officer as they were Patels and Shanbhog holding offices of profit under Mysore Government, disqualified under Art. 191

anchor.surface_text: The numberination papers filed by three persons, namely, Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao for election from that companystituency were rejected by the Returning Officer on the ground that the first two of them were Patels and the third a Shanbhog of certain villages in Mysore and as such they were all holders of offices of profit under the Mysore Government and companysequently disqualified from membership of the Assembly under Art. 191.

facts.text: Appellant declared elected after rejection left two candidates, appellant obtained larger number of votes

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this rejection two candidates were left to companytest the election and the appellant, who was one of them, was declared elected as he obtained the larger number of votes at the poll.

facts.text: Six electors of Harihar constituency filed election petition under s.100(1)(c) Representation of the People Act, 1951 claiming improper rejection of nominations

anchor.surface_text: Six electors of the Haribar companystituency then filed the election petition for a declaration under s. 100  1  c  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, that the election of the appellant was void on the ground that the numberination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao had been improperly rejected.

facts.text: Election Tribunal dismissed petition on September 10, 1957 holding Patels and Shanbhogs hold offices of profit

anchor.surface_text: The petition was dismissed by the Election Tribunal by its order dated September 10, 1957. It held that the companyditions of service of Patels and Shanbhogs were regulated by 1170 the Mysore Village Offices Act, 1908,

facts.text: Mysore High Court allowed appeal on February 26, 1958 declaring appellant's election void, holding Patels and Shanbhogs not offices under Government

anchor.surface_text: The six petitioners then appealed to the High Court of Mysore. The High Court by its judgment, dated February 26, 1958, allowed the appeal and held that the offices of Patels and Shanbhogs were number offices under the Government. The election of the appellant was thereupon declared void.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133(1)(c)

anchor.surface_text: It is from this judgment that the present appeal to this Court has been taken with a certificate granted under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: One of six petitioners dead, remaining five respondents

anchor.surface_text: One of the six petitioners being dead, the remaining five are the respondents in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that Hantimanthappa and Siddappa held the offices of Patels and as remuneration for their services lands had been allotted to them and provision for cash allowances made.

facts.text: Guru Rao was Shanbhog with cash remuneration

anchor.surface_text: Likewise it is number disputed that Guru Rao was a Shanbbog and had cash remuneration provided to him for his services.

facts.text: Patels and Shanbhogs have specific duties and are holders of offices

anchor.surface_text: It is also clear and number challenged that Patels and Shanbhogs have specific duties to perform and are holders of offices.

facts.text: Offices governed by Mysore Village Offices Act, 1908

anchor.surface_text: Village Offices are number governed by the Mysore Village Offices Act, 1908. The election petition proceeds on this basis and both the Courts below have so held and the companytrary has indeed number been companytended in this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court judgment, restored Election Tribunal order, dismissed election petition

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, therefore, succeeds and is allowed. The judgment and order of the High Court are set aside, and those of the Election Tribunal restored. The election petition is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It 1169 arises out of a petition presented under the Representation of the People Act, 1951, for a declaration that the election of the appellant was void. The election with which the case is companycerned, was held on March 8, 1957, for choosing members for the Mysore State Legislative Assembly.

It is from this judgment that the present appeal to this Court has been taken with a certificate granted under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution. One of the six petitioners being dead, the remaining five are the respondents in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: First, there is s. 6 under which when two or more villages or portions thereof are grouped together or amalgamated to form a new village, or one village is divided into 2 or more villages, the old village offices cease to exist and new offices have to be created. issues.text: The question for decision in this appeal is whether certain persons were holders of offices of profit under the Government and were therefore disqualified under Art. 191 of the Constitution, for being chosen as members of a legislative assembly.

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision in this appeal is whether certain persons were holders of offices of profit under the Government and were therefore disqualified under Art. 191 of the Constitution, for being chosen as members of a legislative assemb

issues.text: The only point for determination in this appeal is whether they are holders of offices under the Mysore Government.

issues.text: whether the nomination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao had been improperly rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The nomination papers filed by three persons, namely, Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao for election from that constituency were rejected by the Returning Officer on the ground that the first two of them were Patels and the third a Shanbhog of certain villages in Mysore and as such they were all holders of offices of profit under the Mysore Government and consequently disqualified from membership of the Assembly under Art. 191.

issues.text: what is the effect of the provisions of the Mysore Village Offices Act dealing with the hereditary right to the offices?

anchor.surface_text: The question then is, what is the effect of the provisions of the Mysore Village Offices Act dealing with the hereditary right to the offices? First, there is s. 6 under which when two or more villages or portions thereof are grouped together or amalgamated to form a new village, or one village is divided into 2 or more villages, the old village offices cease to exist and new offices have to be created.

issues.text: does this make the office one not under the Government?

anchor.surface_text: Let us, however, ignore the restrictions on the hereditary right to the office mentioned in the Act and assume that the eldest heir in the eldest branch of the last holder of it, is entitled to succeed to the office when he vacates it. The question is, does this make the office one not under the Government?

issues.text: does it follow that because a village officer cannot be dismissed at the pleasure of the Governor, he does not hold office under the Government?

anchor.surface_text: But does it follow that because a village officer cannot be dismissed at the pleasure of the Governor, he does not hold office under the Government? It has been recognised that a statute may prevent an officer of the Government from being dismissed at its pleasure.

anchor.surface_text: It is also clear and not challenged that Patels and Shanbhogs have specific duties to perform and are holders of offices. The only point for determination in this appeal is whether they are holders of offices under the Mysore Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Governed by Mysore Village Offices Act; Government appoints even heirs; controls, remunerates, removes

holdings.text: Hereditary right to village offices does not make the office one not under the Government; appointment by Government perfects the right

anchor.surface_text: The Government makes the appointment to the office though it may be that it has under the statute no option but to appoint the heir to the office if he has fulfilled the statutory requirements. The office is, therefore, held by reason of the appointment by the Government and not simply because of a hereditary right to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ss.6,8 require Government selection/appointment even from families/heirs; heir holds only upon appointment; no corporate village community

holdings.text: Even assuming absolute hereditary right, the office is held under the Government as appointment is by it and no one else

anchor.surface_text: Let us, however, ignore the restrictions on the hereditary right to the office mentioned in the Act and assume that the eldest heir in the eldest branch of the last holder of it, is entitled to succeed to the office when he vacates it. The question is, does this make the office one not under the Government ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointment by Government required; office cannot be held under no one; village communities lack corporate existence; distinguished Mangal Sain

holdings.text: A village officer cannot be dismissed at the pleasure of the Governor does not mean he does not hold office under the Government

anchor.surface_text: But does it follow that because a village officer cannot be dismissed at the pleasure of the Governor, he does not hold office under the Government? It has been recognised that a statute may prevent an officer of the Government from being dismissed at its pleasure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutes can limit dismissal at pleasure (Gould v Stuart); s.7 provides for removal but does not negate under Government

holdings.text: Cash allowances deducted from revenue are payment by Government out of its moneys; lands allotted by Government as emoluments

anchor.surface_text: Government lands are allotted by it to the officers by way of emoluments for services to be rendered and the cash allowances are also fixed by the Government. ... The Rules provide that where an officer deducts the cash allowance from the revenue collected by him and deposits the balance in the Government Treasury, his receipt for the amount deducted shall be considered equivalent to the payment into the Treasury of an equal sum in cash

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revenue belongs to Government; deduction treated as deposit and repayment per rule 75(XIII); fixed by Government

holdings.text: Duties of village officers fixed by Government; they work under direction, control and supervision of Government

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, we find that the duties of the village officers are fixed by the Government and these officers work under the direction, control and supervision of the Government. This is conceded.

anchor.surface_text: All these clearly establish that Patels and shanbhogs hold offices of profit under the Government. In this view of the matter it has to be held that the nomination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao were rightly rejected by the Returning Officer
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and is allowed. The judgment and order of the High Court are set aside, and those of the Election Tribunal restored. The election petition is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding of rightful rejection negates the ground of improper rejection under Section 100(1)(c)

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter it has to be held that the nomination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao were rightly rejected by the Returning Officer and the election petition is without substance.
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and is allowed. The judgment and order of the High Court are set aside, and those of the Election Tribunal restored. The election petition is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It is also clear and not challenged that Patels and Shanbhogs have specific duties to perform and are holders of offices. The only point for determination in this appeal is whether they are holders of offices under the Mysore Government.
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and is allowed. The judgment and order of the High Court are set aside, and those of the Election Tribunal restored. The election petition is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The Government makes the appointment to the office though it may be that it has under the statute no option but to appoint the heir to the office if he has fulfilled the statutory requirements. The office is, therefore, held by reason of the appointment by the Government and not simply because of a hereditary right to it.

edges.explanation: Holding h5 addresses issue i5 by concluding that even assuming absolute hereditary right, the office is held under the Government due to appointment by it.

anchor.surface_text: Let us, however, ignore the restrictions on the hereditary right to the office mentioned in the Act and assume that the eldest heir in the eldest branch of the last holder of it, is entitled to succeed to the office when he vacates it. The question is, does this make the office one not under the Government ?
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and is allowed. The judgment and order of the High Court are set aside, and those of the Election Tribunal restored. The election petition is dismissed.

But does it follow that because a village officer cannot be dismissed at the pleasure of the Governor, he does not hold office under the Government? It has been recognised that a statute may prevent an officer of the Government from being dismissed at its pleasure.
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and is allowed. The judgment and order of the High Court are set aside, and those of the Election Tribunal restored. The election petition is dismissed.
